# Historical dueling in antebellum Tallahassee

}}
Several duels during the antebellum era shaped Tallahassee's history. In this era, dueling is defined as the preferred means of conflict resolution among gentlemen. For Tallahassee, it was a frontier town during the territorial period, which meant it was more subject to lawlessness and following the Southern honor code. These factors, along with the political climate of Antebellum Tallahassee led to several duels throughout the 19th century that shaped Tallahassee's history.
Dueling in Tallahassee went beyond serving as a form of dispute amongst lawyers and politicians. It created historically significant geographic locations such as Oak at Old Magnolia Road and Mannington, and places named after famous duelers such as Murat Street and McComb Street. There are also many notable duels that have shaped not only Tallahassee's local society, but also legal regulations. Such duels include Prince Achille Murat vs. Judge David Betton Macomb, Sr. (1826), Colonel Augustus Alston vs. George Taliaferro Ward, and Colonel Augustus Alston vs. Florida Militia Brigadier General Leigh Read.
After the fall out of Alston-Read duel, Tallahassee residents elected a new mayor who would put an end to the lawlessness and dueling of Tallahassee, Florida. Nevertheless, dueling remains a main part of Tallahassee's historical culture and reputation as "the Duel Capital of the South."
Contributing factors
Politics and law
Politics and law were deeply tied to dueling in the Antebellum Tallahassee era because of the social importance of honor and how disputes were resolved among elites. Typically, duels were amongst lawyers and politicians of the area, therefore having to do with politics. Politics in the antebellum South and Tallahassee were not simply about policy, they involved personal reputation and public image of the politicians passing them. That's why when political issues arise amongst lawyers and politicians, they were dealt with through duels; not in the courtroom. In the duels, politicians were expected to defend their character from accusations, and if they didn't, they may risk being seen as a "weak leader" or a "coward". In this way, dueling became a way to publicly prove courage and defend one's reputation, which was a central part of being a "good" leader. Additionally, Tallahassee during the Antebellum era was typically denoted as "lawless" and "disorderly" with little government regulation. In turn, this made dueling seem like the most reasonable way to resolve conflict. Even when laws were passed that banned dueling, they were often ignored or circumvented. Specifically in 1832, Florida Legislative Council passed a law that forbade dueling, and even though a legislative act was passed, it was often disregarded since many of the men comprising the Florida Legislative Council partook in dueling and many others dueled in secrecy.
Social class
Along with politics and law, social class is also rooted in dueling in the Antebellum Tallahassee era because of the association dueling has with honor. During the antebellum era, elite members gained reputation and status over land ownership and political power. Additionally, a man's honor depended on his success as master of his family, business, and property. Typically, lower classes might fight with knives or fists, but the elite southerners, specifically "gentleman", used pistols in duels to mark their social status. Dueling was mostly practiced by the upper classes including politicians, lawyers, and military officials. Because dueling was associated with honor and status, the upper middle classes and elite classes might've felt this obligation to partake in dueling to prove they belong amongst the high social classes. All in all, social class had a huge influence on dueling in the South and Tallahassee during the antebellum era, since it was closely tied to the Southern honor culture and the elite social status.
Dueling grounds in Tallahassee
Over time, several spots in Tallahassee have become depicted as traditional dueling grounds. Some of the most important ones include "Dueling Oak" on Old Magnolia Road, Mannington (on the Florida-Georgia border), Houston Hill, and the St. Marks region.
Dueling Oak on Old Magnolia Road
Old Magnolia Road is home to a large southern Quercus virginiana oak tree. It is situated roughly in the middle of Old Magnolia Road, which is a road that's east of Tallahassee, not used often, and is partially unpaved. This road is part of the "canopy roads" system in Leon County. The canopy roads consist of roads that were historically plantation routes surrounded by oak trees, forming tunnel-like borders. Typically, the trees are so central in these systems of roads that traffic must detour around them, which is why it's not a popular road to travel on.
Historians aren't entirely sure how the Quercus virginiana oak tree earned the name "Dueling Oak", since there is no definitive evidence that can confirm a duel actually occurred at Old Magnolia Road, but, the name Dueling Oak reflects Tallahassee's once prominent dueling culture.
Mannington
Mannington was a small, isolated community near the Florida-Georgia line in Leon County. It is often cited in dueling accounts as a location just across the Florida-Georgia border, where extralegal practices were likely to take place and enforcement was weak.
Because dueling was illegal in Florida after 1832, border areas offered a legal "safe spot" because of the unclear jurisdiction. Specifically, the Murat v. Macomb and Read-Alston duel of December 12, 1839 took place at Mannington. Mannington eventually became the traditional place to duel in town because the state line was disputed.
Houston Hill
Houston Hill is named in some duel histories as a local spot near Lake Lafayette. Famous duels such as Alston vs. Ward are known for taking place north of Tallahassee at Houston Hills. Additionally, there is confusion on where the Read-Alston duel actually took place. Most historic accounts say Mannington, but a few say Houston Hill. Because records are inconsistent on whether certain duels actually took place at Houston Hill, it became apart of the general dueling landscape, rather than a singular dueling site.
St. Marks and the state line of Alabama
Some duels were said to have taken place across state lines, either near borders like Mannington or along rivers or uninhabited islands where law enforcement was weak. In addition to Mannington, some duels were arranged near the St. Marks region or the state line of Alabama to evade jurisdiction. Benefits of dueling in places like St. Marks and near borders included easy accessibility to a remote area and duelists could argue that they were meeting beyond the law. Famous duels such as Baltzell vs. Westcott took place near the state line of Alabama, but there is little to no evidence of duels ever taking place in the St. Marks region. As a result, the St. Marks region gained the same amount of recognition as Houston Hill did, where it because apart of the general dueling landscape, rather than a specific dueling site.
Notable duels
Tallahassee is known for four famous duels which are Prince Achillee Murat vs. Judge David Betton Macomb, Sr. (1826), Thomas Baltzell vs. James Diament Westcott, Junior (1832), The Alston Duels: Colonel Augustus Alston vs. George Taliaferro Ward, and The Alston Duels: Colonel Augustus Alston vs. Florida Militia Brigadier General Leigh Read.
Prince Achillee Murat vs. Judge David Betton Macomb, Sr. (1826)
The feud between Murat and Macomb began after Murat's slaves allegedly stole hogs from Macomb, and tensions rises when Murat publicly called Macomb a "turncoat" and Macomb called Murat a "damned infernal liar". They dueled at Mannington, near the Georgia border, where Murat admitted he was at fault before Macomb arrived. This led them to not shoot to kill and resulted in Murat's shot going right through Macomb's clothing and Macomb's shot taking off half of the little finger of Murat's right hand. The duel restored both men's honor. Despite the violence, Murat later because Justice of the Peace in Jefferson County, and Macomb became a judge, advocating for dueling, showing that it didn't necessarily harm political or social standing.
Thomas Baltzell vs. James Diament Westcott, Junior (1832)
Baltzell and Westcott likely dueled over political or banking disputes near the Alabama state line. At the time, Westcott was the Secretary of the Territory and Baltzell was a lawyer. In the duel, Westcott was injured, but the two eventually settled their differences and ended on good terms. They went on to work together at Florida's Constitutional Convention of 1838-1839, and Baltzell eventually became Chief Justice of Florida, while Westcott became a state senator and his son later joined the state Supreme Court. This duel shows how political rivalries often turned violent but did prevent duelists from making a mark in society.
The Alston duels: Colonel Augustus Alston vs. George Taliaferro Ward
The duel between Alston and Ward arose after Ward horsewhipped Alston over the death of his nephew during the Second Seminole War. Alston, the central figure, was the leader of the Florida Whig Party, while Ward moved to Tallahassee as a young boy around 1825, and once he reached adulthood, he married into the Chaires family and inherited Southwood Plantation. He also was involved in the Territorial Council (1837-1838), Florida's Constitutional Convention, and Union Bank. They met at Houston Hill near Lake Lafayette, where Alston wounded Ward, but the duel ended without a final resolution. Before they could meet up to finish what they had started, Alston continued to duel while Ward served in the Civil War and died in battle. This duel highlights how personal and family disputes could escalate into violence, and how elite families used dueling to defend honor.
The Alston duels: Colonel Augustus Alston vs. Florida Militia Brigadier General Leigh Read
Augustus Alston's duel with Leigh Read was politically motivated, representing the conflict between the Whigs and Democrats over banking and territorial power. Read represented the opposing political party, seeing as he was the leader of the Florida Democrat party and Alston was the head of the Whig Party in Florida. The duel took place at Mannington and resulted in the death of Alston. As a result, this led to a cycle of violent outbreaks: Alston's brother, Willis, attempted multiple times and finally succeeded in murdering Read in 1841. The whole situation caused public outrage, leading citizens to elect Franics Eppes to restore order and do away with the dueling culture. It demonstrated how dueling and political violence shaped Tallahassee society and highlighted the weaknesses of law enforcement during the territorial period. Finally, this duel is especially important as it led to the end of dueling culture in Tallahassee, Florida.
Social, cultural, and political significance
Over the years, dueling has had a lasting social, cultural, and political impact on shaping Tallahassee back then and today.
Social and cultural significance
Dueling played a huge role in shaping the cultural performance and social institution of territorial Florida. Beyond settling disputes, dueling reinforced social class and upheld the "Code Duello", a system of rules that dictated how gentlemen should handle conflict. This code allowed men to maintain their reputations by showing courage, even if the duel itself didn't result in fatalities or deaths. In Tallahassee, this meant that elite men relied on dueling not just to restore honor, but also maintain their high social standing. By publicly proving their bravery, they preserved their social standing in a community where reputation was often more valuable than legal justice. In this way, dueling was less about the actual outcome of the fight and more about conforming to a shared cultural expectation that tied masculinity, violence, and respect together.
Political significance
Dueling in Tallahassee was not only to resolve personal conflict but also political conflict, which ultimately shaped Florida's early political struggles and legislative system today. Specifically, the Alston-Read duel of 1839 was an important political case that became the turning point in reforming Tallahassee's legislative system. The duel showcased the clash between political parties, the Whigs and the Democrats, and more importantly reflected the divisions over banking, governance, and territorial power. What made this duel especially significant was its aftermath: a series of attempted murders that showed the fatalities that can arise from political duels. The disorder shocked citizens, who began demanding leaders to restore law and stability. This pressure helped weaken public support of dueling as a means of resolving conflicts and contributed to a shift towards a more structured government, especially as Florida moved closer to becoming an established state. In this sense, dueling played a role in not only helping solve political consequences during the Antebellum era but also shaping Tallahassee's legislative system today as it forced citizens to realize the dangers of dueling in public life.
Legal and political responses
Legal and political responses to dueling in Tallahassee, Florida show how lawmakers, officials, and the press struggled to control the practice of dueling that was socially accepted amongst the public, yet dangerous in the long run.
Territorial and state laws banning dueling
The Florida Territorial Legislature first attempted to ban dueling in 1832 through the passing of an anti-dueling statute. This statute said that any individual who was caught participating in a duel would be fined $500 and could face up to one year in prison. However, this statute ended up having no effect and was merely an ironic symbol of Florida's corrupt system. This is mainly because the legislators implementing the statue had dueled or supported duelists, so it resulted in legislators repealing and weakening their own anti-dueling law, which led to the unbanning of dueling. All in all, dueling remained this loosely regulated and often ignored way of solving disputes, which would later result in many consequences in Florida's society.
Enforcement by local authorities
As stated above, enforcement by authorities was often weak, despite the laws prohibiting dueling. Additionally, duelists often found ways around the prohibitions placed, such as holding their duels near boundaries or across state lines to avoid heavy prosecution. Also, many officials and legislators often disregarded duelists since many of them were prominent men in society such as lawyers, plantation owners, and policy makers. However, after the Alston-Read duel and the aftermath that followed, the public began to demand for stronger policies. As a result, Francis Eppes was elected as the mayor in 1841 and appointed six officers to address lawlessness, ultimately establishing the beginning of a local police force. Yet even then, it wasn't until the Southern honor code began to diminish that these policies were actually enforced.
Role of newspapers in publicizing duels and shaping public opinion
Newspapers played a crucial role in causing and showcasing duels, as well as shaping the pubic's opinion on dueling. The editorial and "communications" columns typically published accusations of dishonor, making them public and sparking conversations. In the Read-Alston duel, for instance, several newspaper columns accused Read of breaking the code of honor. This eventually spread throughout the community, intensifying the whole situation. After the Read-Alston duel and the heavy violence that stemmed from it, press coverage turned more critical of dueling and its negative consequences. As a result, newspapers played a major role in shaping public opinion, first by skewing coverage of a duel towards particular points of view, and later by becoming an important force in bringing dueling to an end.
Legacy
Although dueling ended in the mid 1800s, its legacy still lives on in Tallahassee through street names, museums, and cultural significance, reminding us of its powerful role in shaping Tallahassee during the Antebellum era and present day.
Historical memory
Dueling left a lasting impact on Tallahassee's history and culture. Although dueling has not been in practice since the mid 1800s, its influence remains today. Street names such as Murat Street and McComb street honor well-known duelists, while sites like Old Magnolia Road still carry the title "Dueling Oak". Despite its prevalent role in shaping politics, law, and society in Tallahassee during the Antebellum era, the amount of historic presence is often overlooked.
Modern recognition
Today, dueling is recognized mainly through museums. For example, The Museum of Florida History includes exhibits from the territorial period that highlights dueling's importance. Additionally, the Union Bank Museum displays artifacts connected to that era such as duelists pistols. Yet, the history of dueling in Tallahassee is not widely discussed, even though it helped define the city's reputation as the "Duel Capital of the South". Nevertheless, greater recognition is needed to understand how dueling shaped Florida's current identity and to preserve this important part of the beginning of Tallahassee's transition to an orderly society and Southern history in general.
